subcategory: Reluctance among women to pursue top management positions
description: This refers to the phenomenon where women are less likely to pursue or attain leadership roles in organizations. Despite some progress toward gender equality in the workplace, women continue to be underrepresented in top management positions, such as CEOs, executives, and board members,

content.text: Presence of self-limiting beliefs in females because of the environment and culture women are brought up in.
Women underestimate their capabilities and try not to choose those options that require more work.
Girls usually see their brothers and fathers making decisions about the house, which impacts their ability to take up leadership roles later in life.
Male colleagues usually label female co-workers as their ‘sisters’ or ‘daughters,’ which subjugates women, as culturally, these relations are considered below men.
Absence of women in leadership roles within the workplace demotivates other young women.
The patriarchal beliefs that families and instructors repeatedly reinforce affect women’s perceptions of their capabilities.
Public encouragement of women’s accomplishments to gather support from their families and communities, as it plays a key role in shaping the ambitions of a woman and how she views herself.
Multiple stakeholders should take steps in their own capacities to bring in females in all kinds of roles, groom and develop them, and take them to senior-level positions.
Promote leadership that has international exposure so they act as ambassadors for other females to step up.
Organizations and media should conduct experience-sharing sessions with existing female leaders to inspire others.
All stakeholders should figure out the advantages of diversity and inclusion through compassion and teamwork.
